results.title: A Different type of game
results.creator_credit: Stephen Hodges, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The games men play - how cricket and the Aussie male ethos played a major part in Stephen’s adolescent years and on into his adult life. He learnt to play the game and the game never dies.

results.title: My life to study
results.creator_credit: Fei Hu Song, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Fei Hu Song and his family came from China to Australia, they all took English language courses. This began for Hu Song a lifetime of study and of making Australia his home.

results.title: Straford video memories
results.creator_credit: John Straford, Frank Straford and Inala Video
results.brief_description:
Video memories of the Victorian west coast and bushfires in the north-east produced by the Straford family.
“Gone to blazes” contains footage broadcast by national and commercial TV channels during the course of the devastating bushfires that ravaged the Victorian north-east early in 2003.

results.title: Old man: new world
results.brief_description: The life of an Old Man is viewed unfolding before us, jumping like memory through time and through everyday spaces with the blinking quickness of an edit. From shot to shot and from screen to screen, a life re-editing itself. Through the ‘old’ eyes of the central character, we glimpse anew the details of our ordinary world and time.

results.title: Spin
results.brief_description: Pirated satellite feeds revealing U.S. media personalities’ contemptuous plans for their viewers come full circle in Spin. TV out-takes appropriated from network satellite feeds unravel the tightly spun fabric of television, a system which silences public debates and furthers the intolerance of anyone outside the pack of journalists, politicians, spin doctors, and televangelists who manufacture the news. Spin moves through the L.A. rebellion and the 1992 floating TV talk-show called the U.S. Presidential election.

results.title: The Passing
results.creator_credit: Artists' Television Workshop at WXXI/TV, Rochester, TV Lab at WNET/Thirteen and Bill Viola
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description:
Engaged in projects all over the world, Bill Viola has become one of the most celebrated artists working with the moving image. His installations are admired for the lightness with which they address weighty themes: birth, death, the nature of time and impermanence, the mania of individuality contending with the benefits and responsibilities of the human, communal condition. Time and again, Viola organises his installations around dramatic ‘moments of distinction’, like the breath coming in and out of a body distinguishing vitality from mortality, or the blinking eye distinguishing the energy in light from the absence that
is darkness.

In The Passing viewers watch a man - the artist - sleep, and they also witness visions that emerge from his unconscious. As they are bathed in the glow of the dreamer’s imaginary, as they sway to the pulsing of the engulfing soundtrack and feel the dimensions of their own body altering in response to the shifts of scale and variations of weightlessness, they sense a slow but profound shift in their consciousness.

Time passes in an unaccustomed manner, basic emotions like fear and attraction seem to offer themselves for fresh consideration. There is no pre-defined, ‘right’ duration for an encounter with this work. Visitors tend to stay for as long as it takes to feel an alteration; this can be ten seconds, or it can be hours. The Passing might have a beginning, middle and end mapped into its 52-minute linear duration, but the installation is best regarded as an endless loop that circulates like an enormous conceptual mantra, always available for engagement and orientation. No matter where in the timeline a viewer first submerges into The Passing, they will almost instantly find themselves attuned to rhythms and
glimmers that can guide them along their own passage through memory and self-examination to enlightenment.

results.title: Storm and stress
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: A line of satellite dishes stretches to the horizon as storm clouds loom overhead. A tornado funnels across a plains landscape at high speed. Through remarkable imagery of majestic natural phenomena, Storm and Stress evokes the beauty, terror and power of the tension between the forces of nature and technology. Hall’s sequences are based on natural elements — air, fire, water — and the industrial counterparts that echo them — wind tunnels, Tesla coils, hydroelectric plants. Hall’s allusions to Sturm und Drang, the 19th-century Romantic aesthetic of the apocalyptic sublime, and the notion of the Pathetic Fallacy, in which natural upheaval reflects the individual’s inner turmoil, are expressed through powerful visual metaphors.

results.title: Video 50
results.creator_credit: Robert Boner, Caroline Arrighi, Robert Wilson and Film and Video Collectif and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen (ZDF)
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Video 50 is an extraordinary video sketchbook, a highly original, visually dramatic and frequently humorous collection of one hundred abbreviated ‘episodes’ produced for television. Unfolding as a series of thirty-second vignettes, this enigmatic essay in style is characterized by a deadpan theatricality, symbolist imagery, surrealist juxtapositions and repetition of key visual motifs. Indelible images, precisely composed — a man teetering above a waterfall, a floating chair, a winking eye, a parrot against the New York skyline — are accompanied by an ‘architectural’ sound score that includes spoken ‘phonetic patterns’ rather than words. Fusing his surprising visual logic and rhythms with unexpected temporal manipulations, Wilson creates a work of startling wit and poetry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Boner, Caroline Arrighi, Robert Wilson and Film and Video Collectif and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen (ZDF)

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

Selected highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:49:00 - Title card Story ‘The Bear’
00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’
